keyTakeAways: Indigenous knowledge, including natural signs like rainfall patterns, animal behavior, and sound cues, is being used effectively by local communities in northern Pakistan to predict and respond to glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs).

Despite significant government spending on technological early warning systems (EWS), such systems are frequently perceived as unreliable due to malfunctions, lack of real-time connectivity, and poor community engagement.

Residents in Gilgit-Baltistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa have demonstrated high levels of trust in human-based early warning systems passed down through generations, such as gunfire signals or fire alarms, which have successfully saved lives during floods.

The lack of trust in official EWS systems is compounded by reports of incomplete implementation, lack of follow-up, and political misrepresentation of system effectiveness, leading to community skepticism and reliance on local knowledge.

Pakistan, despite contributing less than 1% to global emissions, is among the top 10 most climate-vulnerable nations due to rising temperatures and glacial melt, with average temperature increases of 1.3°C since the 1950s.
A 2023 World Bank report confirms that climate change is intensifying glacial melt and increasing the frequency of GLOFs, especially in mountainous regions like Gilgit-Baltistan.

The UNDP identifies systemic issues—such as weak institutional capacity, communication gaps, and data uncertainties—as major challenges to effective EWS implementation globally, including in Pakistan.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In northern Pakistan’s mountainous regions, especially in Gilgit-Baltistan, Indigenous knowledge—such as recognizing unusual animal behavior, cloud formations, and loud sounds like glacier bursts—is being used effectively by local shepherds to detect and warn of glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs). Despite government investment in technological early warning systems (EWS), such as sensors and sirens, these systems have failed to gain community trust due to malfunctions, lack of real-time integration, and poor engagement with local populations. A $37 million GLOF-II project launched in 2017 has not led to operational success, with reports of non-functioning equipment and no official follow-up. In contrast, stories from shepherds like Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain demonstrate that traditional human-based signals—such as gunfire or fire alarms—have successfully saved lives. Pakistan, a top 10 climate-vulnerable nation with a 1.3°C temperature rise since the 1950s, faces increasing GLOF frequency due to glacial melt, and the article underscores the urgent need for integrating traditional Indigenous knowledge with modern systems to build climate resilience.
title: How Indigenous knowledge is aiding Pakistan’s fight against climate change
